subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 23 March, on motion by Senator Ellison:
That these bills be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I am tempted to describe this as bulk-billing, but that is a very poor pun. The opposition will not oppose the legislation contained in the Commonwealth Places (Mirror Taxes) Bill , the Commonwealth Places Windfall Tax (Collection) Bill , the Commonwealth Places Windfall Tax (Imposition) Bill and the Commonwealth Places (Consequential Amendments) Bill . The bills seek to deal with specific issues raised in the High Court decision in 1996 in Alders International Pty Ltd v. the Commissioner of State Revenue in Victoria.

speech.para: That decision is well-known to honourable senators wherein the High Court ruled that certain stamp duties on leases covering Commonwealth places were constitutionally invalid. The opposition believes that the proposals contained in this legislation are a satisfactory approach to dealing with the issues there. On that basis, we do not oppose the bills.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard my speech on the second reading of these bills.

speech.para: Leave granted.

The 4 bills, the Commonwealth Places (Mirror Taxes) Bill 1998, the Commonwealth Places (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1998, the Commonwealth Places Windfall Tax (Imposition) Bill 1998, and the Commonwealth Places Windfall Tax (Collection) Bill 1998 seek to deal with the issues raised in the 1996 High Court decision in Allders International Pty Ltd v Commissioner of State Revenue (Victoria).

This case held that a state stamp duty on a lease covering part of a Commonwealth place—ie Commonwealth land and/or building—was constitutionally invalid. The reasoning employed in the case means that it follows logically that other state taxes may also be invalid.

Apparently the Commonwealth has been advised that, as well as the various types of stamp duty that are levied by the states, some of the other taxes raises at the state level such as payroll tax, financial institutions duty and debits taxes may also be constitutionally invalid.
Clearly, this situation poses a threat to the revenue bases of the states. Unsurprisingly these other governments have accordingly requested the Commonwealth to enact this legislation.
The threat to the states involves both future revenue streams, and the more significant issue of the compulsory refunding of all taxes previously collected concerning Commonwealth places.

Accordingly, under this package of legislation the Commonwealth will impose "mirror" (ie identical) taxes on Commonwealth places to those that would prevail if the Commonwealth places were not owned by the Commonwealth.

The revenue from these mirror taxes (payroll tax, stamp duties, financial institutions duties and debits taxes) will be on-passed to the relevant states. That is, even though the Commonwealth will be raising the revenue, there is a commitment that all of the revenue will be raised for the financial benefit of the states
This is a fair and workable solution to the constitutional issues raised in the Allsop decision and will not be opposed by Labor.

The second important point to recognise about the mirror taxes regime is the extent of the regime. At the moment the legislation (specifically schedule 1 of the Commonwealth Places (Mirror Taxes) Bill) applies to only those state taxes which are individually listed.
Provision is also made to extend the scope of the mirror taxes regime by regulation should the need arise.

This is achieved by the definition of "state taxing law" in clause 3 of the Commonwealth Places (Mirror Taxes) Bill including any tax which is prescribed in regulations to the bill. At present there are no such regulations. However, Labor supports this situation as it will mean that if any state does introduce such a tax in the future then its addition to this package of legislation will be able to be achieved quickly and efficiently, without the need for the passage of specific legislation.
Of course, this regulation will be disallowable by either House and therefore this does not represent an unreasonable delegation of what is really a technical revenue issue.

The third major issue covered by these bills is the question of windfall refunds. Where the courts hold that taxes are unconstitutionally imposed, then all of the collections of the tax must be refunded to the relevant taxpayers. This means that all of the stamp duty considered in Allsops case ever collected from taxpayers relating to Commonwealth places must be refunded to the registered taxpayers.
The problems with refunds of this type are twofold.

Firstly, the cost to the various state governments of making tax refunds will necessarily impact on the level of resources available to finance health, eduction, law and order and other essential services.
We do not know what the potential scope of the refunds would be if this legislation is not passed, but I assume that the figure is in the tens of millions of dollars across all of the states.
Secondly, the refunds will flow to the legal taxpayer. Normally businesses which pay taxes pass the economic effect of the tax on to their customers through their pricing structure.
Accordingly, if those taxes were then refunded to the taxpayer that would represent a windfall to those businesses because they have already passed on the tax to consumers.
So this legislation is fair, both for users of state services and to avoid an unfair windfall to be handed to some taxpayers.
To protect the states from having to refund all past tax collections relating to Commonwealth places, a 100% windfall tax is imposed by the Commonwealth on all such refunds.

This is achieved by the state deducting the windfall tax, at the rate of 100%, from the refund before it is paid. The taxpayer is notified in the refund notice that the windfall tax has been deducted. The refund tax is then remitted to the Commonwealth. The liability to make this payment to the Commonwealth creates a liability in the Commonwealth to pay an equal amount to the state.
Although being a complex process this means that no windfall gains will accrue to taxpayers at the expense of the states.

A similar windfall tax model was implemented to overcome the High Court decision in the Ha & Lim, and Walter Hammond cases last year which invalidated the business franchise fees collected by the states.
Accordingly, for all of the reasons I have just detailed the Opposition will not be opposing this package of legislation.

talk.start.para: —The Indigenous Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1997 adjusts for cost supplementation a range of grants payable under schedule 2 of the Indigenous Education (Supplementary Assistance) Act. It also removes the requirement that at least 10 per cent of students in an educational institution be indigenous for the institution to be eligible for per capita payments under the supplementary recurrent assistance. Supplementary recurrent assistance is part of the Commonwealth's indigenous education strategic initiatives program—IESIP. IESIP has become outcome, rather than input, focused, a direction set by the previous government when it announced additional funding for this and other indigenous education programs in response to the 1994 review of Aboriginal education.

speech.para: The announcement by the Labor government in September 1995 also flagged the change to per capita recurrent funding, which was put in place last year. In doing so, however, the coalition restricted access to funding by requiring non-government schools, preschools and vocational education institutions to have indigenous students make up at least 10 per cent of their total enrolments and also have a minimum number of indigenous students enrolled. For schools and vocational educational institutions, the minimum requirement is 20 indigenous students, and for preschools it is set at five students.
In his speech on the 1996 legislation, which introduced the current arrangement, Dr Kemp said:
The per capita element of the Aboriginal education strategic initiative program will provide an entitle ment-based, equitable recurrent funding arrangement.

Yet this program has not operated equitably. It will not be truly equitable until it does not discriminate between one indigenous student and another. With a year 12 retention rate of some 33 per cent and three times the rate of primary school literacy problems as other students, indigenous students face massive problems. Yet, under the government's original proposal in relation to this bill, some 1,100 indigenous students would still be denied access to IESIP recurrent assistance. These are students in non-systemic schools with fewer than 20 indigenous students enrolled.

When this bill was debated in the House of Representatives, the opposition moved an amendment which would have removed the minimum enrolment requirement along with the 10 per cent rule. We questioned the reasons for the government's objection to allowing every indigenous student access to these funds. We also put forward ideas about how claimed administrative difficulties—the signing of around 260 extra agreements with the affected schools—could be addressed.

I am pleased to say that the response from the government has met the concerns of the opposition and will mean that no indigenous students need miss out on the per capita funding. Legal advice confirms that the Indigenous Education (Supplementary Assistance) Act gives the Commonwealth the power to sign agreements with bodies representing groups of students whose individual enrolment of indigenous students is below the minimum specified in legislation or with a single school representing a group. National peak bodies representing the non-government schools sector have all expressed satisfaction with this outcome. Because of this, the opposition has been prepared to drop its amendments. We look forward to these funds helping indigenous young people benefit more from education.

talk.start.para: —I thank the opposition for its support on this matter and commend the bill to the Senate.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

The opposition supports the passage of the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill 1997 . That information is provided as part of the process of evaluating and listing the particular products on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods, which in turn enables such goods to be put on sale in Australia.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Parer, Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, does the government propose to adopt the recommendations of the Industry Commission's report on the coal industry; what advantages does the government expect to flow to the industry as a consequence; and what benefits will this bring to those who have invested in it?

—The government, of course, only received the Industry Commission report yesterday. It will be carefully studying the report and looking at any ways it can provide assistance through its facilitation units to help achieve the necessary changes to the lift in productivity. The coal industry is our largest export industry. The Industry Commission has forecast that, with the proper increase of productivity and proper use of capital equipment, the export income could increase from today's figure of about $8.8 billion to around $12 billion by the year 2009.

answer.para: On a preliminary look at the Industry Commission report, there were mixed results. Some mines were doing well, particularly new mines and some of the older ones that had adapted to modern conditions to face competition from other countries. I think it is worth pointing out that, notwithstanding the recent fallout in Asia, it is still expected that the growth in demand for the industry will be substantial. Australia is the world's largest exporter of both steaming coal and coking coal. It is by no means the biggest producer. The biggest producer of coal is China at about 1.4 billion tonnes, followed by the United States at about 900 million or thereabouts and India at about 400-odd million tonnes.

It is in the interests of the country, it is in the interests of the industry, it is in the interest of the companies and it is in the interest of the employees that they look very carefully at what is called restrictive work practices; I think the other term that is used is custom and habit, or words to that effect. There is no doubt that we do not have a monopoly on sales around the world. There are other countries which would like to compete with us. Growth has certainly been forecast, and it is important that we as a country not only maintain our leadership in the world as the major exporter, but also that we capture the vast majority of the growth that is forecast.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask Senator Parer a supplementary question. Minister, as you have participated in a so-called employee share scheme, which has nothing to do with the real workers in the industry and everything to do with you and a few cronies on the board, will you now concede that productivity in the industry would go up if workers had the opportunity to invest 44c and collect $56,300? Or is that just a privilege that is reserved for part-time directors, especially those who are on a full-time parliamentary salary, generous superannuation and other entitlements?

—Here we have Senator Faulkner going back regurgitating all the things that I explained in detail over the past few weeks. Madam President, let me tell you that Senator Faulkner will go to any depths to try to smear people. Yesterday he came in here and indicated that I had not put my name in a directorship of a particular company called Duffcombe. Let me just tell Senator Faulkner this, and I hesitate to do it because it is a personal matter. I was involved with that company. Do you know why? Because I had a sister who had a very nasty marriage breakdown, and I filled in that position. You came in here yesterday and said I should have disclosed that.
—When I came in here yesterday I asked you questions, and we will continue to ask you questions.
—Let me tell you this, Senator Faulkner, that company was deregistered in—
—We will continue to ask you questions.
—Senator Faulkner!
—That company was deregistered in 1993.
—You can guarantee that—
—Senator Faulkner!
—Why don't you, Senator Faulkner—

answer.para: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Why don't you, Senator Faulkner—

answer.para: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Why don't you apologise, Senator Faulkner?

—I raise a point of order, Madam President. Surely it is the height of hypocrisy for Senator Faulkner to ask a question and then do his absolute best to ensure that not a word of the answer can be heard.
—It is in breach of the standing orders, without doubt. Senator Parer, had you finished your answer?
—Yes, Madam President.
—My question is to the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman. Minister, the vast majority of frail older Australians wish to continue living in their own homes.
—Order! Senators on both sides will cease interjecting. Senator Patterson.
—Minister, the vast majority of frail—
—That includes you, Senator Schacht.

—The vast majority of frail older Australians wish to continue living in their own homes. How will the $270 million package announced today by the Prime Minister help older Australians achieve this aim, and will you outline the increased support for carers of frail older Australians?
—I thank Senator Patterson—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senators on my left will cease interjecting.

—I do thank Senator Patterson for her very important question and I acknowledge the long advocacy and concern that she has had for older Australians. It is a pity that the Labor opposition are not even prepared to listen to the answer to the question.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —They are not interested in social policy reform, as the government is and as Senator Patterson is. Today's announcement by the Prime Minister is a very important one for older Australians: for those who want to stay in their home if they choose as well as for those who help to care for them. After all, the majority of Australians do want to stay in their home as they age. There is $270 million over the next four years to help older Australians to stay at home and improve the support for their carers, those who were rightly described by the Prime Minister today as the unsung heroes of our society.

answer.para: Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Carr, stop shouting.

—I recognise that the Labor Party does not want anybody to hear this answer but I would think that listeners do. Community aged care packages are to be expanded by 3,900 at a cost of $92 million over the next four years, more than doubling the number of people assisted. Continence assistance—badly needed by many older Australians—is being increased. The Labor Party did nothing about it in government. That has been increased at a cost of $15 million to make it easier for older people to manage at home.

answer.para: Under the carer respite centres initiative, which was announced originally in 1996, the number of centres will be expanded in the coming year from 58 to 73 at a cost of $30 million. An extra $10 million will be spent on additional respite care places for people with dementia. We remember that in the 13 long years of Labor they walked away from people with dementia and their carers. There will be an extra $15 million over four years for accommodation services for about 8,000 people who are aged over 65 and who care for adult children with a profound disability—desperately needed. That has never been done before and many of these people have been carers for 40 years or more—most, but not all, are women.

In my portfolio of social security, income support for carers is to be improved with eligibility for the new carers allowance to be expanded, providing assistance to an extra 14,000 carers at a cost of another $91 million over the next four years. Funding for aged care assessment teams is to be indexed to growth in the older population so as to enable people to access care appropriate to their needs and to reduce the waiting period of people to be assessed—a cost of $13.7 million. That is a significant package of great assistance to older Australians who want to stay in their homes. It will also help the people who care for them in their homes.

This is the third tranche of measures to help carers and older people since this government came into office. In the first budget when we had such an enormous deficit we put in place some measures. In the last budget we put in another lot of measures, including raising the domiciliary nursing care benefit by something like 28 per cent. The carers allowance is going to come into effect on 1 July next year and it will combine the child disability allowance and the domiciliary nursing care benefit as well as widen eligibility. It will provide assistance to an extra 14,000 carers.

The carer allowance will include new eligibility conditions to ensure that carers of people with high care needs and multiple disabilities and those caring for people needing constant supervision can access the payment. Under the current eligibility requirements for the domiciliary nursing care benefit these people may not qualify for payment. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you were outlining how the new carers allowance will improve the delivery of income. Would you continue with that?

—I would be very happy to make it absolutely clear that the increase in the domiciliary nursing care benefit from $58.30 to $75.10 per fortnight takes place on 1 July this year. Many of these other measures will take place on 1 July next year. The new carer allowance will mean that carers looking after people with high support needs will be recognised and will be eligible for the allowance.

answer.para: The government has also been working on improving the administration of our social security system so that it is easier for carers to access the assistance they need. There will be a new method of assessing adult disabilities. It will be a fairer method and it will be more understandable. It has never been done before. It will be delivered through the Department of Social Security—a one-stop shop at Centrelink. The task of carers is difficult enough without unnecessary obstacles being put in their path to accessing the assistance they need.
This government has had extensive consultations with carers associations and Senator Patterson has had consultations with the older community. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's Gallery of Fiame Naomi Mataafa, the Minister for Education from Samoa. I welcome you to the chamber and wish you a pleasant and happy visit to this country.
—Hear, hear!

—Madam President, my question is to Senator Kemp. Minister, are you aware that in the last budget the Treasurer announced a crackdown on the practice of private companies distributing profits effectively tax free by structuring them as loans to shareholders rather than as taxable dividends? Are you aware that the Treasurer described this scam as `a tax minimisation practice used by some high wealth individuals,' and estimated revenue loss through this rort at $110 million over three years, and that while most budget and tax measures operate from the date of announcement, the relevant provisions of the amendment bill currently in the House will not operate from the budget date but rather from the date of introduction in the House, some seven months later? Given the government's delay, isn't this just another example of this government's hypocritical treatment of the scams used by high wealth individuals at the expense of Australia's battlers?

—I was hoping that Senator Cook would ask a question like this. This comes from a man who fought tooth and nail to protect one of the greatest tax rorts in our system—R&D syndicates. This is the man who convinced his own party room and colleagues not to fight this big scam and he continues still to support it. This is also the man who decided that the high wealth people, including himself, should not pay the superannuation surcharge. This is the man who wanted to protect high wealth people.
—Rubbish; absolute rubbish!

—`Rubbish,' says Senator Ray. Don't you know how you voted, Senator Ray, on that bill? That is the second point I would make. The third point is that, after 13 years in office, in the election campaign the Keating government, of which Senator Cook was a minister, decided there were problems with high wealth people paying taxes—after 13 years.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —So let me make it quite clear that to get a question like this from Senator Cook is quite astonishing.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Turning to the substance of the question, section 108, which the Labor Party did nothing about when it was in government—

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on both sides are interjecting too frequently.
—As I was saying, the government has brought in a measure—

—Which I trust, Senator, you will be voting for—not like your usual habits on these measures. This is a measure which was brought in to tax companies that disguise loans from private companies. This was announced by the Treasurer and this measure is now in a bill before the other place. It will be coming to this chamber and I only hope, in contrast to other measures dealing with tax avoidance, we will receive the support of the Labor Party.

—I ask the minister, are you aware of the allegations in the document lodged with the Queensland Supreme Court last week that this mechanism was put in place by the private company Queensland Coal Mine Management Pty Ltd between 1990 and 1993 to distribute notional dividends to directors and senior employees? —Again, I remind the Senate that this was the Senator who fought tooth and nail to protect one of the biggest tax rorts, R&D syndicates. This was that particular senator. Senator, section 108 operated under your government. You chose not to change the law. You chose not to change the law in this particular area, this government has chosen to change the law. We make no apology for that. —My question is to Senator Alston, the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, has your attention been drawn to the statement in today's paper that the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, was `anything other than a willing, even zealous, privatiser'? talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Yes, I have read with a great deal of interest the article by Kenneth Davidson in today's Age . I am sure everyone who follows the media in this country would know that Kenneth Davidson has been a mouthpiece for Telstra for very many years. He has never said anything that appealed to me for as long as I can remember and he certainly does not go out of his way to criticise the Labor Party. What does he say? The headline reads:

answer.para: Is Beazley the great Telstra pretender?
He says:
Within weeks of the 1990 election, a letter from Hawke to Beazley setting out the plan to sell Qantas and Australian Airlines and introduce competition for Telecom (Telstra) was leaked to the press.
Beazley was one of the ministers leading the privatisation charge at the special ALP conference in 1990 . . .
And on it goes. He also says, very damningly:

If Beazley is to have any credibility in the debate over privatising the remaining two-thirds of Telstra, he must either admit the privatisation and competition policies . . . were wrong, or he has to explain why full privatisation of Telstra is different to, say, full privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank.
Of course, Mr Beazley has more form than Reggie and Ronnie Kray combined. The fact is that even Kenneth Davidson, who is absolutely opposed to any form of privatisation, ends up saying this:
Yet if a Beazley Government hung on to Telstra and used it as a milch cow—
as Keating did to the tune of $3 billion—

What a damning indictment. Is it any wonder that that mistress of the little ironies, Cheryl Kernot, said back in 1995 in relation to Labor's privatisation plans:

It is a very serious issue. Some of the research that I have seen suggests that some people regard Mr Beazley as a bit of a likeable buffoon. They are absolutely dead wrong because this is a totally unprincipled Labor Party led by someone who is a clone of the New South Wales Right school, the whatever-it-takes merchants. . . . I am alleged to have said to him that I favoured the privatisation of Telstra. I have never had a conversation suggesting that particular proposition on my part . . .

He has been flushed out. He has been forced to try and come clean but he has not. These are weasel words. Kenneth Davidson does not believe it; his article makes that clear. I do not believe it and the Australian public will not believe it. If he says, `I have never favoured the privatisation of Telstra,' let him tell us precisely what was said in that conversation.
As Kenneth Davidson makes very plain, Kim Beazley has privatised everything that moved. As Cheryl Kernot says,

`I mean, the Labor Party is just similar to the Liberal Party. It's Kim Beazley as finance minister who has been involved with the sale of the Commonwealth Bank and with the sale of Qantas. Labor, of course, will lie their heads off in opposition and say they will not privatise, but as soon as they get there they will take the money and the box.

—Senator, I did not hear what was said and who made the comment.
—Madam President, there are continuing offensive remarks whenever Democrats ask questions, and I ask that that one be withdrawn.
—Senator Lees, my problem is I do not know to which senator you refer. I heard interjections but I do not know who made it or what.
—I left it to her conscience, Madam President, and I therefore shall proceed.
—Order!
—My question is directed to the minister representing the Minister for Family Services.
—Order! Senators on both sides—
—Senators on both sides need to maintain sufficient silence so that I can hear the question.

—This is a serious question. Isn't it the case, Minister, that the extra $15 million announced for ageing carers—that is, those over 65 who are looking after adult children with disabilities, many of them for more than 40 years—amounts to $9 per week per carer? Was the Prime Minister really serious when he presented this pittance as a great social bonus flowing from the $7 billion your government has taken out of community services over the last couple of years? Isn't this rather more heartbreaking than groundbreaking?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Lees for the question because it is a very serious question. It is a very serious matter regarding the carers of people with disabilities and keeping people in their homes. The important aspect of it is that this government, for the first time ever, has done something about the problem. It was never done by the Labor Party in government; it was never addressed by them at all.

answer.para: The important aspect of it is that we are doing something about it because 93 per cent of elderly people are in their own homes. Despite all the bleatings that occur on the other side about nursing homes and nursing hostels, only seven per cent of the whole population actually go into nursing homes and hostels. The 93 per cent of older Australians who live at home will be assisted in some aspects where this is necessary. This government is committed to helping frail, older Australians achieve what they want most: quality care in their own homes.
Madam President, I take it that Senator Lees is standing because she is going to say that I am not answering her question.

talk.start.para: —This is not the question.

—The point of the matter is that I am answering the question. I want to put it in context so that she that gets an answer to the question. Some people have no choice but to enter residential care, and we are committed to ensuring that they receive the highest standards of care and accommodation.
—There is a point of order. Senator Lees?
—Point of—
—Are you going to apologise to Senator Crane?
—Thank you, Senator Abetz.
—Are you going to apologise to Senator Crane?
—Senator Abetz!

—It is a point of order on relevance. I said very clearly that the part of the package was not the part on aged care packages but the section dealing with carers of people with severe disabilities in their home.
—I draw your attention to the question, Senator Herron.

—I did refer to that in the context that the total package in relation to aged care is $210 million over four years, so they have a choice. In relation to the disability carers and the introduction of that package, the significance, as I said, is that it is the first time a government has done something about it. I think even Senator Lees will accept that. They may not accept it on the other side but it is a fact. It is something that is being done for the first time in relation to people looking after disabled people in their homes. We have not only introduced it but we are providing funding for that.

answer.para: I have learnt, Senator Lees, not to accept statements that are made in questions in this chamber without verifying the facts. You can do creative accounting, as you well know, in relation to these matters. I will come back to you with a response from the minister and a breakdown of the figures so that we can assess whether what you have alleged in your question is correct. I will come back with a response from the minister when it is available.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I can assure you that we have checked and rechecked our figures because I did not believe it at first. It does not matter which calculator you use. I will not go through those now because I want to ask an additional question.
—Why don't you have the good grace to get your facts straight?
—Senator Patterson!
—Well, she should get her facts right.
—Senator Patterson!
—She comes in here with this rubbish.
—Senator Patterson!

—Thank you, Senator Patterson. Minister, is it not the case that this new funding—this amazing social bonus—represents less than one cent from every dollar that your government has hacked off Australia's health, education and social welfare budgets?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Senator Lees has shown her ignorance because this is still being negotiated. She has trotted out figures that are not true, because it is still being negotiated. The Commonwealth will increase its spending on disability services considerably over the next five years. Its outlays will increase from $555 million in 1997-98 to $655 million—an 18 per cent increase—over the next five years. Part of the Commonwealth increase will be given to the states to assist them in meeting their specific responsibilities. This will increase from $316 million to $383 million over the next five years, an increase of 21 per cent.

answer.para: The Commonwealth will also increase its own direct spending on employment and related services from $238 million to $272 million, an increase of 14 per cent. So Senator Lees, I would check your facts. I will come back and if I have anything further to add from the minister, I will give it to you.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs.
—Senator O'Brien, just a moment. Senators on my right, I need to hear the question.

—Is the minister aware that at a meeting of the south-east regional Liberal conference in South Australia in March, which was attended by six Liberal politicians, including Senator Ferris and the Minister for Defence, the following resolutions were passed:

question.para: The convention calls for Mr John Anderson, Federal Minister for Primary Industries, to impose temporary import quota restrictions to assist those primary industries experiencing damage from volume imports as they adjust to free trade.

This convention calls upon Mr Warren Truss, Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs, to provide absolute and complete labelling laws, nationwide, that clearly identifies products which contain imported ingredients.
Does the minister support these resolutions passed by this Liberal Party conference?

talk.start.para: —Just a moment, Senator Parer.
—What about your Hobart conference? What about the power sell-off in New South Wales?
—Senator Heffernan! Senator Parer.
—I am unaware of the resolutions passed at the conference in South Australia to which Senator O'Brien refers.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are far too many interjections and the chamber is behaving—
—Do you know what happened to the Labor conference in Queensland?
—Senator Herron!
—Do you know what happened in the Labor conference in Queensland?
—Senator Herron, stop shouting across the chamber.

—I might say, it is a major function of Liberal Party conferences to look at various motions and pass them on to people in parliament. I have no information on the detail of that. I will look at it and if there is anything I have to add, I will come back and respond to you accordingly.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, perhaps you can answer this or perhaps you will need to take it to the minister and get a response later. In the light of significant levels of imported pig meat and the collapse in the prices being received by local growers for this product, which are now well below the cost of production, will the minister reconsider the level of assistance currently being provided to the pig industry to help it adjust to the impact of these imports? I can assure you that that is the position the industry takes.

—It would have been good if you had asked that the first time. The $10 million development fund for Australia's pig meat industry will aim to boost competitiveness and prise open new high return markets for the pig industry. Terms of reference for the new pig industry and export development scheme were unveiled by Mr Anderson in talks with the Pork Council of Australia. The industry will work directly with the government in recommending funding priorities.

answer.para: Mr Anderson actually put a deadline at the end of this month—the end of March had been set for determining an initial blueprint. This would include developing an industry business plan to identify production, process, marketing and barriers to export market developments. It will identify strategies and activities to overcome the barriers most effectively and efficiently and it will be determining market development objectives and market access priorities.

Minister Anderson said the committee would also be charged with evaluating additional sources of assistance from government agencies to supplement the $10 million allocated through the pig meat industry export development committee. Six-monthly reports and the implementation of projects and strategies will be required.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. Following a recent report by the Australian Communications Authority, is it reasonable to expect that members of the federal parliament would have significant concerns about the quality of service provided by Telstra? Does that report highlight unacceptable performance deficits in Telstra's service? Can the minister advise whether he is concerned about the contents of this report and, if so, whether he has made known his views to the highest level of Telstra in relation to the organisation's current quality of service? Further, I ask whether the minister considers that the responsibility for the apparent decline in service rests with the Chief Executive Officer of Telstra, its board, or both?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I think the recent report from the ACA does provide figures which are of concern to the government. That is why we made it plain the other day that we did not think it was acceptable that there should be lower levels of service than people in the bush are entitled to expect. That is, indeed, why we have introduced a new penalty regime: to ensure that it simply cannot continue at that level.

answer.para: For all those on this side who like to pretend that somehow everything flows from privatisation and nothing from the competition which Mr Beazley introduced back in 1991, or the privatisation that he was dead keen on at that same time, it is worth just remembering that the fact is that, in March 1973, the figures for agreed completion dates—

talk.start.para: —March when—1973?

—March 1993. The figures for rural areas on agreed completion dates for new services are the same now as they were then. Madam President, if you look at fault clearances, what you find is that, back in March 1993, the national figures were the same as they were in December 1996. In fact, when we came to government they were 66 per cent, they went up seven per cent to 73, and they have gone back down again to about that same level now. So the fact is that these figures have moved around a bit.

answer.para: The big difference between the approach we take and the approach that Labor take is that they did nothing about it. They simply ignored the bush. That is why they paid the supreme penalty.
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The people in the bush realised you could not give a damn. That is why we acknowledged that this standard of service was not good enough prior to the election, by promising to introduce the customer service guarantee—and we did. We put the carriers on notice that we expected them to lift their game. We are now making it clear that there will be very draconian penalties attached if they do not.

answer.para: So I want to make it very clear to Senator Colston and all those over here that it is not good enough to have declining standards. And I was very pleased to see Telstra actually put out a press release, following these results, in which it said it plans to improve its customer service to at least the customer service guarantee levels. That is very encouraging news.

talk.start.para: —That's a good one; very big of them!

—If they did not have to waste their time listening to this performer over here, the dinosaur—the Jurassic Park expert, as Mr Brumby calls him—then they would be able to get on with the job a lot better. Telstra itself accepts that the customer service guarantee is perfectly achievable, that it is a standard that ought to be met—and they have undertaken to meet it. I find that very encouraging.

answer.para: But just remember that this quality of performance concern goes back a long way. In fact, Senator Heffernan pointed out to me the other day that it took him 15 years to get a new connection back in the 1980s. And I can well remember, back in the late 80s early 90s, being told that Telstra simply would not come out at weekends for fault connections because they did not want to have to pay all that overtime that the people who pay your salaries think is so important.

It is also I think very significant that, in an interview the other day on ABC metropolitan radio in Brisbane, Linda Wattie from the Australian Telecommunications Users Group was asked about the new penalty regime, and she said, `It is certainly better than no check or balance that has been the case in the past.' In other words, she was saying that under Labor nothing was done about declining levels of quality of service.

I simply assure Senator Colston that people are entitled to be concerned. They should also be encouraged that we are taking action to ensure that low levels of service cannot occur in the future. I have, indeed, taken the matter up at the highest level. I have spoken to Mr Blount, and I am very confident that we will have a new regime in place. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs. I refer to the Anti-Dumping Authority's report No. 185, which was presented to the minister yesterday. Minister, can you tell the Senate whether the minister for customs will reject the ADA's finding that the amount of paper dumped by Belgium, France, the Netherlands, Switzerland and Taiwan is negligible because, according to the ADA, it constitutes only seven per cent of the total Australian import volume? Will the government instead commit to imposing anti-dumping duties upon the relevant companies, on the grounds that no level of dumping is acceptable when people's jobs are at stake?

—What the senator is referring to, I think, is the anti-dumping action against the coated wood-free papers from the 14 countries. He will know, because he canvassed it very well in estimates—I might say, Senator Murphy—that the investigation itself is highly complex in terms of the nature of the industry concerned and the number of countries and companies involved; and that Customs worked closely with Australian industry to ensure that all relevant issues were addressed.

answer.para: The investigation was extended to a full 120 days prescribed by the legislation, due to the difficulty of undertaking verification visits—in Europe, because of the summer holidays there; and in Korea, because of national festivities. A large volume of information about exporters was not available to other interested parties until late in the investigation period.

The case was there for a further 14 days to allow interested parties to comment on this information. This enabled Customs to consider these comments before reaching its preliminary finding. The results of the investigation by Customs itself were that they found there was sufficient ground for the publication of a dumping duty notice for goods exported from Austria, Belgium, Finland, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the Republic of Korea, the Netherlands, Switzerland and Taiwan. There were not sufficient grounds for the publication of a dumping duty notice for certain goods exported from Finland, the Republic of South Africa and Sweden. Customs terminated the investigation in relation to certain exporters from Belgium, France, Germany, Indonesia and Italy, and securities were imposed on 13 companies from eight countries.

The positive findings were then subject to review by the anti-dumping authority. It supported Customs' termination of investigations into exporters from Belgium, France, Germany, Indonesia and Italy. It also agreed with Customs' finding that the bagasse paper was not a like good but has initiated its own inquiry into whether coated paper weighing less than 90 grams and coated paper of A3 quality were like goods or not. As regards the recent one that came down yesterday, I will seek further information from the minister to see whether there is any further action that will be required.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I thank you for the part answer that you gave, but you did not really address the question with regard to whether or not the government will reject the ADA findings and impose any duties. I guess that is part of the problem. I wonder whether or not the minister is going to tell the workers at the Wesley Vale paper mill in Tasmania that the loss of their jobs as a result of the so-called negligible amount of dumped paper is an acceptable price to pay for the government's failure to introduce legislation to improve the anti-dumping laws of this country. Isn't this just another example in the long list of the Prime Minister's non-core promises for which Australians again must pay?
—Senator Murphy will be aware of the fact that the minister has changed the whole system of dumping.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order!
—He has announced that he has reviewed the system of dumping. There is a new anti-dumping regime which you would be aware of.
—When are you going to bring the legislation in?
—Ha! Well, Madam President—

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are far too many senators interjecting.
—I will see if I can—

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Parer, would you just resume your seat for a moment, please. The level of interjection is totally disorderly and unacceptable. Senator Parer.
—This was announced by the minister I think on about 14 March but there have been changes.
—You are a bit vague.
—I will get more detail from the minister.
—What you announced was that you were going to get some legislation together. When are you going to introduce it into the parliament?

—If that is what you are asking me, I will refer it to the minister. I guess that he will introduce it as soon as possible. But the way you people carry on in this place, it is very hard to get legislation through anyway.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron. It relates to the Labor Party's Hindmarsh Island Bridge fiasco which has to date cost Australian taxpayers in excess of $5 million. Minister, what are the implications of the High Court decision which makes a mockery of Labor's handling of the Hindmarsh Island Bridge issue? Further, Minister, what does this mean for those Aboriginal women who have always argued that there was never any secret women's business?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Ferguson for the question. Senator Ferguson, of course, is a South Australian senator who is very knowledgeable in this matter.
—A great senator.

—He is a great senator who has taken a keen interest in this matter. Let me first comment on a group of Ngarrindjeri women who have been consistent and strong throughout the nine years of the Hindmarsh Island Bridge debacle. These women are senior elders of the Ngarrindjeri people. They include Dorothy Wilson, Bertha Gollan, Dulcie Wilson, Audrey Dix and Jenny Grace. These Ngarrindjeri women have consistently maintained that there was no secret women's business and therefore no reason to stop construction of the bridge. They have now been totally vindicated. They are unsung heroes. For their trouble, they have been vilified by sections of their community and by Senator Bolkus and others from the loony Left of the Labor Party. To a large extent their views have been ignored by many in the media who choose instead to listen only to a particular group of Ngarrindjeri people.

answer.para: Senator Bolkus, the former minister, Robert Tickner, and the present shadow minister, Daryl Melham, have now been ruled wrong over Hindmarsh Island not once but on four very expensive occasions. Over a nine-year period there have been three inquiries, a royal commission and a High Court challenge. Four of the five processes found the bridge should proceed, and I can confirm, Senator Ferguson, that over $5 million of taxpayers' money has been wasted by Labor in pursuit of this expensive ideological obsession. If they had one shred of decency, Senator Bolkus, Daryl Melham and Labor would offer Dorothy Wilson, Bertha Gollan, Audrey Dix, Jenny Grace and Dulcie Wilson a very public and humble apology.
Let me now deal with Senator Bolkus. I know this will not come as a surprise to the senators beside me and behind me.

talk.start.para: —Why don't you apologise to the stolen generation?
—Senator Bolkus has been running around offering the media bad advice—
—Order! Senator Herron, just a moment. Senator Bolkus, cease shouting.
—Madam President—
—You have not been called upon to speak.
—Sit down you sleazy little weasel.
—I raise a point of order, Madam President. I was asked a question. My response for the record was, `Why don't you apologise to the stolen generation?'It has to go on the record.
—There is no point of order, sit down.
—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Can you ask Senator Alston to withdraw those absolutely despicable comments he just directed at Senator Bolkus?
—Senator Alston?
—I withdraw.

—Senator Bolkus has been running around offering the media bad advice on the High Court decision. Despite desperate claims to the contrary by him, the High Court decision has clearly denied the opposition any basis for successfully arguing that the Native Title Amendment Bill is unconstitutional. Considering Senator Bolkus's pathetic judgment and legal advice of late, I am amazed that anybody in the media would listen to him. Just look at his judgment in releasing the confidential Federal Court Skase information—`Nick the Leak'—and the Dolly Dunn case, and his strong support for the failed High Court challenge to the Hindmarsh Island Bridge.

answer.para: Senator Bolkus, three strikes and you are out in this game. We have had three strikes from you. It is time you were relieved. Madam President, he is clearly not fit to be shadow Attorney-General. For those in the media who were absolutely suckered—even the Sydney Morning Herald and the ABC should have had the sense to treat whatever Senator Bolkus said with considerable scepticism. Three strikes, Senator Bolkus; time you were put on the backbench.

I see that one of the newspapers today said that it was a terrible thing for the government—and Senator Bolkus obviously fed them that line—that this has occurred. I would explain to Senator Bolkus what the Hindmarsh Island judges determined. It was a simple decision, Senator Bolkus. I would refer anybody to the Hansard of 5 February 1997 when Senator Bolkus, in discussing it, said how very complicated and difficult it all was. The judgment was admirably reported in the Australian today. The report said:

Most judges gave a simple reason when discussing it. The Hindmarsh bridge law amended another federal law about Aboriginal heritage. Everyone agreed the heritage law was valid under the race power. So if Parliament can validly pass a law under a constitutional power, it must be able to amend it.

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Herron, there was a phrase referring to Senator Bolkus in your answer that I would ask you to withdraw.
—Could you tell me what it was, Madam President? I can only withdraw something if I am aware.
—You referred to `Nick the Leak'. I regard that as unacceptable and unparliamentary. I ask for it to be withdrawn.
—He has been convicted by this parliament—unanimously, except for those who follow him—of leaking.
—Senator Alston, resume your seat! Senator Herron, I ask you to withdraw that phrase.
—I withdraw.

subdebateinfo.title: Vocational Education and Training: Media Campaigns

talk.start.para: —My question without notice is to Senator Ellison, Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Minister, is it the case that—
—Order! Senator Ellison needs to hear this.

—Minister, is it the case that your government has allocated $11.2 million this financial year to run media campaigns for vocational education and training and Employment National? Given the massive budget cuts to DEETYA and the thousands of jobs stripped from the Public Service, how can you justify the spending of millions of dollars on party political advertising? Why should Dr Kemp have a political advertising slush fund of $11.2 million in an election year? Isn't it the case that Dr Kemp has attempted to cover up his consultancy binge within DEETYA to conceal the fact that your government is using departmental consultancies for market research and other matters of a direct political nature? Is this why the department has given three conflicting answers to estimates on these matters?

—Madam President, once again you can see that the opposition is really scraping the barrel for good questions today. I can tell you right now that Senator Carr would have us not let the people of Australia know about the new Jobs Network that we have introduced. The opposition would have us not let them know about the various services that we provide—jobs matching, jobs training, intensive assistance, enterprise. The fact is that they are upset that we have come up with a very good system to assist unemployed people to pursue jobs and find jobs, and they do want us to let the people of Australia know about it.

answer.para: It is only appropriate that the government let the people of Australia know that we have five services available: job matching, job search training, intensive assistance, the new enterprise incentive scheme that I mentioned, and new apprenticeships and traineeships. I suppose that they do not want us to let people in the community know that these programs are around. Labor did it. Labor did it when it was in government and, as a responsible government, we are letting people in Australia know about these programs. We have 1,400 sites, Senator Carr—more than previously existed—and we have to let the people of Australia know that these sites are there so that they can go to them.

If you think that is wrong, you tell that to the unemployed people who want to know about these programs. You tell that to those people who want intensive training. You tell that to those people who want to know more about traineeships and apprenticeships. You tell that to those unemployed people who are interested in looking at setting up an enterprise to change their lives and to start up a new business. You tell them, `Look, we don't want you to know about this. We don't want the government to advertise what it's doing.' You tell them that and we will see what they say to you.

This Jobs Network program is working extremely well. It is one of the largest tenders ever, and these private providers will provide more opportunities for people to find work. I would say to Senator Carr that he ought to look more at the lack of policy on their side. What are they going to do for the unemployed? I might just remind you that in seasonally adjusted and trend terms we now have 8.1 per cent unemployment—the lowest it has been for a long time.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, will you confirm that Employment National will be spending $6.9 million on TV and other advertisements featuring mostly unemployed persons not eligible for government assistance? Can you also confirm that $3.6 million, of which $1.8 million will be spent between now and the end of the financial year, will be spent on promoting controversial vocational education and training programs? Why shouldn't the Liberal Party be paying for its own propaganda, or is this yet another attempt by Dr Kemp to promote himself within the government?

—If Senator Carr thinks that providing vocational education to people in schools and providing more funds for new apprenticeships and traineeships is controversial, then I think he has missed the plot. What we are doing is letting people know—especially young people—what is available. On 1 May, we will have our new apprenticeship centres—a one-stop shop; streamlined approach—for young people to go in and find out what is available and employers will also be able to go in and find out what they can have by way of training programs, whether it be a part-time traineeship or a full-time apprenticeship. Those are the sorts of things that we are about—freeing up the training market and providing more opportunities for young people.

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, the Prime Minister this week sought to assure us that his tax reform package was all about attacking tax avoidance but, Minister, haven't you as a government already ruled out addressing the use of company structures by categories such as personal service workers which have helped lead to over 59 per cent of private companies paying no tax? Minister, I, for one, do not believe that 59 per cent of Australian companies are in trouble. Do you? Haven't you already ruled out addressing family trusts which have an income of around $118 billion? Haven't you ruled out addressing negative gearing, which costs around $1 billion per year? Minister, if your government have ruled out the big three tax minimisation devices, what measures are left to make sure that better-off Australians pay their fair share of tax?

—I thank Senator Murray for that question. Senator Murray, this government has moved in a very forceful manner to crack down on aggressive tax planning and tax avoidance. Indeed, for the information of senators, I will list some of the important measures that we have taken. Where aggressive tax planning schemes come to our attention and where we perceive major problems of tax avoidance, this government will always move to close down loopholes. You mentioned the recent survey. I think you quoted that some 58 per cent of companies pay no tax. I am informed that the number of non-taxable companies has varied between 56 per cent and 61 per cent over the last five years. The majority of non-taxable companies are private companies operating at a loss.

answer.para: But, in the same context, it is also worth bringing to the attention of the Senate—I think from the same statistical journal you were quoting from—the fact that the statistics that were released on 25 March showed that the amount of company net tax payable has continued to rise. I think some people may have got the impression from your question that in fact that was not the case. They show in 1995-96—these are the latest statistics which are available here—that something towards $16 billion of net tax is collected.

I mentioned to you that this government has always moved to crack down on tax avoidance—this is in total contrast to the Labor Party—and to bring greater fairness and equity to the tax system. That is one of the reasons why we brought in the superannuation surcharge, which the Labor Party fought tooth and nail, to the great embarrassment of many of their supporters.

talk.start.para: —That's a new tax.
—Let me list a few measures that have been taken. We abolished—and Senator Cook will know this, because he fought this tooth and nail—R&D syndicates.
—Madam President, I raise a point of order. This is the third time today that this lie has been expressed by the minister.
—Order! Senators on my right!
—Madam President, can you ask this minister to tell the truth about this issue?
—Order! There is no point of order. You may debate answers given in question time at a later time.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. You required the minister for aboriginal affairs to withdraw the term `Nick the Leak', albeit that the Senate had censured Senator Bolkus for undertaking that activity. But during that point of order, Senator Cook made the deliberate reference to Senator Kemp lying. If we are going to apply the standing orders, I suggest that they be applied to Senator Cook as well and he ought to be asked to withdraw it.
—Senator Cook, if your interjection implied that Senator Kemp was lying, it should be withdrawn.
—To the extent it was—
—Just withdraw.
—Hang on. Madam President, Senator Kemp did not tell the truth—although I am not quite sure how I expressed that—when he referred to me and tax avoidance. He did not tell the truth.
—Senator Cook, you are debating the issue. I ask you to withdraw the imputation.
—If standing orders require me to do that, I withdraw.
—He repeated it.
—He withdrew. Senator Kemp, have you finished answering the question? There is still more time available if you wish to continue.
—No, Madam President, I have not. I am well used to receiving abuse from Senator Cook. In contrast to previous occasions, that was comparatively mild.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are far too many interjections.

—Before there was that outburst and meltdown from Senator Cook, I was listing some of the measures we have taken. Dare I say it again: I mentioned the moves we took against R&D syndicates. But I am going to move on, having said that, Senator Cook. We took measures relating to foreign companies claiming Australian residence. We took measures relating to thin capitalisation. We of course took a number of other measures relating to the withholding tax provisions to further assist in preventing tax avoidance. This government makes no apology for the actions that we have taken in relation to tax avoidance.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Just a moment, Senator Kemp. There is far too much noise in the chamber.
—In contrast to the previous government and the truly pathetic effort they made in these areas, this government has a very proud record. In conclusion, we have embarked—(Time expired)

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, whether public or private, I am not of the opinion that 59 per cent of Australian companies are in trouble, which would mean that a substantial portion of those companies are hiding tax. What measures will you take to address that problem?
—I can give you some further information on that, Senator Murray.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on my left will stop making so much noise.
—Those opposite have never been interested in serious questions. Sixty per cent of non-taxable companies have a cost of sales greater—
—Madam President, I raise a point of order. It goes to relevance. I would like to know how they are going to address that 59 per cent who do not pay tax.
—I draw your attention to the question, Senator Kemp.

—That was the fastest point of order I have experienced in this chamber. Not bad, Senator Murray. The ATO has established a high level steering committee and working party focusing on tax planning and is diverting resources into tackling schemes as they are identified. This govern ment has a proud record in this area and contrasts very starkly with the pathetic record of the previous government.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—On 26 March Senator McKiernan asked me a supplementary question in my capacity of representing the Attorney. I undertook to seek some clarifying remarks from the Attorney and to provide them to the Senate. I seek leave to have those incorporated in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The remarks read as follows—

Senator VANSTONE: On 26 March 1998 Senator McKiernan asked me a supplementary question, in my capacity as Minister representing the Attorney General, concerning comments made by the Attorney-General about the Dietrich decision and legal aid funding. I undertook to seek some clarifying remarks from the Attorney-General and to provide those to the Senate at a future date.
The Attorney-General has provided the following further remarks in response to Senator McKiernan's supplementary question:
What I have been saying is that it's in the hands of the judges and in the hands of the practitioners who practice in the courts, to curb the length and expense of trials.
We have got to have a system that takes into account the practical realities that there is not unlimited public money available to fund trials.

I believe there is a great potential for shorter and more cost effective trials through reforms in procedures which enable the identification of issues in genuine dispute, the dispensing with strict rules of evidence where appropriate, more disciplined trial management and the use of court presentation technology.
However, experience seems to show that these innovations are only effective where there is the will on the part of lawyers and judges to use them to full advantage for a fair and efficient trial.

The Dietrich case has enormous implications for the legal aid and criminal justice system. In an effort to address the problems caused by increas ingly long trials, a legislative response to the Dietrich decision is only one of a number of possible responses to be considered by SCAG.
The challenge for the criminal justice system is to streamline its court proceedings and practices and restore public confidence in our legal system.

talk.start.para: —In question time yesterday Senator Bartlett asked me a series of questions relating to the Howard government's Cape York Natural Heritage Trust plan. I have made inquiries and received the following information: before the last election the coalition promised to provide up to $40 million from the Natural Heritage Trust to protect the conservation values of Cape York. That commitment has been honoured in full. Up to $40 million is being provided through the Cape York Natural Heritage Trust plan for an integrated package of measures which will protect the region's environmental values and ensure the industries operating in Cape York do so in accordance with the principles of ecologically sustainable development.

speech.para: The plan follows the completion of the Cape York Peninsula land use strategy, CYPLUS, stage 2, which was initiated jointly by the Commonwealth and Queensland governments. The Cape York Natural Heritage Trust plan builds on CYPLUS stage 2 and is consistent with the majority of that report's recommendations in relation to conservation management. The Cape York Natural Heritage Trust plan is being supported by a cross-section of stakeholders on the Cape, and both governments are confident that the plan will be implemented in the spirit of cooperation by the stakeholders in the region.

Senator Bartlett claimed that the government rejected the recommendations of CYPLUS to undertake an assessment of conservation values in the region. This is not the case. Strategy 6 of the plan, which is titled `Assessment of natural and cultural values', provided $250,000 for further assessment work. It is true, however, the government is not waiting for the results of that assessment before getting on with the job. Considerable assessment work was undertaken at the cost of several millions of dollars during CYPLUS stage 1. The government has, therefore, allocated the majority of funds to strategies which will protect the environmental values of the region.

To allow for a higher level of community input and ownership of the process, the Commonwealth and Queensland governments have established a Cape York region advisory panel. That panel includes a cross-section of Cape York interests, including indigenous groups, pastoralists, miners, local government and conservationists. Both governments are aware of concerns that have been raised by indigenous groups and other stakeholders about indigenous representation on the panel. Senator Hill and his Queensland counterpart have been discussing some additions to the panel which will strengthen indigenous representation. I understand that a decision in this respect is expected shortly.
I table a copy of the Cape York Natural Heritage Trust plan, which I suggest Senator Bartlett might like to read.

talk.start.para: —Yesterday Senator Chris Evans asked me a question alleging discrepancy in Natural Heritage Trust figures for the electorate of Gwydir supplied by Senator Hill and announced by the member for Gwydir, Mr Anderson. Many projects cover regions which are not wholly contained within electorate boundaries. Environmental problems do not always fall within electorates, and we have put the resources where they are needed to deal with the environmental problems.

speech.para: Two lists of projects were provided to senators and members. The first lists projects which are clearly identified within electorates; the second lists regional and state projects funded under the Natural Heritage Trust program. It is up to individual MPs as to how they use this list.

I would like to table the list of projects that the minister attached to his electorate announcement. It includes 37 projects with Commonwealth funding of some $780,000 specifically identified in Senator Hill's information as within the electorate of Gwydir. It also includes a further 21 projects with Commonwealth funding of approximately $700,000 which will deliver environmental gains within his electorate and others. Two of these regional projects were used in the announcement made by the minister as examples of natural heritage grants in his electorate—$135,000 for a flood plain management plan for the Namoi River from Carroll to Boggabri; and $110,000 for incentives for implementation of best practices in the Liverpool plains.

I would like to point out that the minister's media release announcing the project contained two errors. Firstly, it said there were 55 projects, where there were actually 58. Secondly, it gave the total funding of $1,402,516, where the correct figure should have been $1,481,266.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Parer) to a question without notice asked by Senator O'Brien today, relating to the importation of pork.
Senator Calvert interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Thank you for that, Senator Calvert. I am glad to see that you are not interested in the pig industry's plight. There are a lot of pig farmers in Tasmania who will be shocked to hear that. The resolutions passed by the south-east regional Liberal conference in South Australia clearly illustrate how tough many people in the bush are finding it under this government.

speech.para: They are not resolutions from a particular farm group. They are not from the ALP. They are not from the Democrats. They are resolutions of the Liberal Party to its Canberra politicians. They are resolutions from rank and file members representing nearly 30 per cent of that state. Importantly, they are resolutions from Liberal Party members who grow grain and wool and run cattle. I understand that there are only two pork producers there. So the view expressed represents a broad population, not just a sectional interest. But don't just take my word for that. I want to quote from a letter which was written after that—

talk.start.para: —It's a pity you weren't there.

—I suppose it was possible that you were there, Senator Ferguson. But I want to quote from a letter from someone else who was there. After that meeting, one participant wrote to me. It is not appropriate to identify that person; no doubt there would be some sort of purge after the event were I to do so. But that particular farmer wrote to me saying:

speech.para: There are many Australians, including politicians, who are ignorant of our plight.
He was obviously a pig producer. He went on:

Having the opportunity to listen and debate Mr Ian McLachlan at the south-east regional conference, with representatives from 30 per cent of regional South Australia, on Saturday last was an eye opener.
I feel Ian McLachlan and our politicians have tunnel vision on free trade and have no interest or sympathy in any industry that cannot survive sudden exposure to free trade.

They have strong support for aquaculture and the wine industry that are currently booming and have no interest in preserving the harmony, balance and diversification that many other industries offer to primary production.

Frankly, he was dead right about the approach of this government to the bush. Given the terms of the resolution passed by that Liberal conference calling on the government to assist these industries, the majority of Liberals in regional South Australia agree with him—except, of course, Mr McLachlan. I wonder, Senator Ferris, how you voted on that matter.

The government is taking the same approach to a number of intensive livestock industries and other industries that could be exposed to imports—for example, the apple and pear industry which AQIS is reviewing with a view to allowing imports from New Zealand and the chicken industry. There has been a massive debate about the introduction of cooked chicken meat recently, and that debate continues. As far as I am aware, the science on the question of introducing cooked chicken meat is far from resolved. Another example is the salmon industry, an industry from my state that has had to fight tooth and nail and which will have to continue to fight tooth and nail because now AQIS is considering opening up trade to New Zealand.

They are all important activities in regional Australia. But I do not think they fit within this government's obsession with free trade at all costs. The costs of this obsession will be jobs in regional Australia. Of course, once the jobs in these industries go, so will the regional communities. That is a fear that I and this side of the chamber have. Now regional Australia is to be put under more pressure with the sale of all of Telstra. The key parts of Australia Post are also now going to be handed over to private interests. So regional Australia is under an extreme attack by this government.

Both sides of this chamber, might I say, are committed to freeing up world trade. Of course we agree that our economic future depends on it. But it is only this side of the chamber, not the government, that is committed to ensuring that industries facing pressure of imports are able to adjust to the changing conditions and given a proper chance to do so and committed to fighting for jobs in regional Australia. The coalition is only interested in the big end of town.

talk.start.para: —I am not surprised that Senator O'Brien raised this issue. But I am surprised that anybody would ever consider writing to Senator O'Brien, being one of the pork producers, when you consider what their attitude was.
—Did they write to you? No!
—I ask you, Senator O'Brien: who was it that signed those World Trade Organisation agreements?
—Senator Ferguson, address your remarks through the chair, please.

—Madam Deputy President, I ask Senator O'Brien: who was actually responsible for signing these agree ments that we are currently working under? When Senator O'Brien says that this government is ignorant of the plight of the bush, he need not return his thoughts very far. He only needs to go back to the election in 1996. I ask, through you, Madam Deputy President, how many seats did the Labor Party actually win in the bush in 1996? That might give you an indication of what they think of your policies and of what you can do for the bush in Australia, Senator O'Brien. How many seats do you hold in rural and regional Australia, Senator O'Brien?
—Is it one or two?
—I think it is one; it may be two.
—Three.

—Three. That is for very good reason. Throughout the whole of the 13 years you were in government you did nothing but destroy rural and regional Australia. You referred to a meeting of the south-east regional convention of the Liberal Party in South Australia, which I was not at, Senator O'Brien, but naturally enough I received very good reports of what happened at that meeting.
—From Senator Ferris?

—My colleague Senator Ferris was there. She was there because she knew that many of these issues would arise that day. One of the issues came from those two pork producers you talk of. I know of those two pork producers, because as well as writing to you, Senator O'Brien, I can promise you that they have written to both Senator Ferris and me.
—You didn't bring home the bacon, did you?

—Senator Ray, the person who brought home the most bacon in this place was the former Prime Minister. He brought home a lot of bacon, and he did very well out of bringing home the bacon in his little piggery. I notice he has got out of it. Perhaps that is because he knew what the effects of his government signing World Trade Organisation agreements would be on his industry.

speech.para: But there are a number of critical issues that are affecting pork producers in Australia today. I speak with some experience, having been involved in the running of an intensive commercial piggery for over 25 years before coming into this place. The problems that are arising today have arisen over a long period when there has always been, as there always is in the production of primary products, cyclical price changes. It is not the first time that we have had an effect on prices from imported products.

You know as well as I know that primary producers in Australia—and I know particularly in my own state of South Australia where we just happen to live in the driest state in the driest continent that is inhabited on earth—have to cope with these difficulties in a way that enables us to continue to be able to survive on the land. The pork producer has written to you, and to everybody else as well, because he wants to highlight the problem that currently exists because there is an influx of imported pork into Australia.
