When you have a government that has no creativity, no scope to look beyond what the simple, lazy policy solutions are, you find a government that has the most clout, the most power and can provide the simplest solution.

We see this government wooing multinational corporations. We see them inviting them to cabinet. We see CEO after CEO of major multinational corporations spending time with the Prime Minister and telling him what he can do for them. The Prime Minister is not telling these corporations what they need to do if they want to get a bite of the Commonwealth government's IT outsourcing cherry. We see these corporations dictating to this government what they demand if this country wants the privilege of their presence here. This is what distinguishes Australia from the rest of the world. What we have is a situation where there are lucrative opportunities in the area of IT outsourcing, but these lucrative opportunities should be there to help foster and grow our own uniquely innovative sector.

One of the important issues is definition. I for one know that there is a complex blend of multinational corporations that employ local people and that distinction becomes quite clouded. But, in the first instance, the Prime Minister must be looking towards the strength of this country and providing our own businesses with opportunities; not excluding them. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to outline to the Senate a tale of shame and sham which has destroyed the lives and hopes of some 250 meatworkers in Grafton, plus the aspirations of hundreds of small businesses in the Clarence Valley who are owed money by a group of companies which have been put under administration. While these companies say they do not have the money to pay the meatworkers and the unsecured creditors, this very group of companies is involved in a joint property development in Melbourne with Delfin corporation which is expected to net this group in excess of $100 million. In spite of this, this group felt so overburdened by debt that they found it necessary to put the two companies that operate the meatworks in Grafton into administration last year, saying that they could no longer afford to pay their unsecured creditors. At the outset, I think it might help the Senate if I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a document entitled `Timeline of the R.J. Gilbertson Group'.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
27th April, 1992 Deed of Cross Guarantee created.
10th June, 1997 Deed of Cross Guarantee created.
26th June, 1997 Deed of Revocation of Class Order lodged in respect of Deed of Cross Guarantee dated 27th April, 1992 as amended.

31 st July, 1997 Gilbertson's Pastoral Company Pty Ltd and Caroline Springs Nominees Pty Ltd create charges in favour of ANZ Banking Group Limited. (These companies had been released from cross guarantees on 26th June, 1997).
10th September, 1997 Marwen Properties creates charge in favour of Suncorp-Metway Limited.
3rd October, 1997 Deed of Revocation of Class Order lodged in respect of Deed of Cross Guarantee created on 10th June, 1997.
7th October, 1997 S.L. Horne and G.J. Kelly appointed Administrators of R.J. Gilbertson (Queensland) Pty Ltd and Giltech Pty Ltd.
13th October, 1997 R.J. Gilbertson (Holdings) Pty Ltd creates charge in favour of Sumikin Bussan International (Australia) Pty Ltd
21st October, 1997 Administrator's report to creditors: "I do not consider it is in the interests of any classes of creditors for the company to be put into liquidation."
30th October, 1997 creditors vote for Deed of Arrangement.
12th December, 1997 meatworks closes.
22nd January, 1998 Administrators write to creditors advising that at least $6 million will need to be received for anything to be available to unsecured creditors.
February, 1998 Ian Causley pushes ASC and Clarke & Company to follow up possible preferences and Deeds of Revocation following information provided by union.
25th March, 1998 Bill O'Chee advised by Clarke & Company that an offer of a further guarantee is on table.
25th March, 1998 George Gilbertson writes to Clarke & Company offering further guarantees.
30th March, 1998 Clarke & Company write to Ian Causley enclosing letter of 25th March, 1997 from George Gilbertson.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave also to table a document which is a letter dated 25 March 1998 addressed to Mr Sterling Horne by Mr George Gilbertson, as well as Australian Securities company searches in relation to the companies Caroline Springs Nominees Pty Ltd, Marwen Investments Pty Ltd and Gilbertson's Pastoral Company Pty Ltd.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I thank the Senate. The basic thrust of what happened is this. The companies in the Gilbertson group were subject to what is called a class order. That meant that the companies could consolidate all of their accounts. To make sure that creditors were not left out of pocket, there was also a deed of cross-guarantee so that each company in the group guaranteed the debts of each of the other companies in the group. There were in fact two deeds of cross-guarantee. The first one was entered into on 27 April 1992 and was amended from time to time. A second deed of cross-guarantee, which was not identical to the first, was entered into on 10 June 1997. On 26 June 1997 the first deed of cross-guarantee was revoked by a deed of revocation of class order. It subsequently transpired that on 3 October 1997 the second deed of cross-guarantee was revoked.

speech.para: Why are these dates important? These dates are important for the following reason. Administrators were appointed to the companies which operate the Grafton Meatworks just four days after the revocation of the second deed of cross-guarantee. So what had happened, of course, was that the cross-guarantees were pulled away, so the rest of the group could sail happily off with the money and two companies, R.J. Gilbertson (Queensland) Pty Ltd and Giltech Pty Ltd, which had incurred all the liabilities in Grafton, were left there unable to pay the creditors. In other words, it was a sham transaction intended for one reason, and that reason was simply to profit the rest of the group at the expense of the workers and the unsecured creditors of Grafton.

The dates are very important because it took a substantial period of time, as it always does, for the deed of revocation which was lodged on 3 October to actually be registered at the Australian Securities Commission. So that when the administrators, Mr S.L. Horne and Mr G.J. Kelly of Clarke and Company in Melbourne, were appointed they did a search, and of course it did not reveal the fact that these guarantees had been pulled out, because the guarantees had only been pulled out three days beforehand. But the shameful thing is this: the directors knew, and the directors did not tell.
So, on 21 October last year, not knowing any better, the administrators wrote a report to creditors which said:
I do not consider it is in the interests of any classes of creditors for the company to be put into liquidation.

Of course, that was not correct, and I will outline to the Senate why that was not correct. That was not correct because, if those companies had been put into liquidation at the meeting which occurred on 30 October last year, both deeds of revocation would have been invalid. A deed of revocation is invalid if within the subsequent six months the companies in question are put into liquidation. But, by putting the companies into administration and a deed of arrangement and not into liquidation, the effect has been that the creditors may not be able to set aside those deeds of revocation. So the creditors in Grafton are left short-changed and the rest of the company is left with all of the assets.

But it is worse than that. As a result of efforts by the honourable member for Page in the other place, Mr Ian Causley, pressure was placed on the Australian Securities Commission and Clarke and Company to follow up about these deeds of revocation. Pressure was placed on the administrators to see that the right thing was done. So the administrators did follow it up and the Australian Securities Commission did follow it up, and full credit to the Australian Securities Commission on that matter.

On 25 March this year, which was just Wednesday of last week, I was informed by a representative of Clarke and Company that a new offer of a guarantee had been put on the table. Indeed, that very day Mr George Gilbertson wrote a letter to Clarke and Company, which I have tabled. I read to honourable senators a seminal portion of that letter. It says:

Caroline Springs Nominees Pty Ltd, Melt Nominees Pty Ltd and Caroline Springs Pty Ltd cannot be included in this indemnity, as those companies are not wholly owned subsidiaries and their only function is to act in a nominee capacity on behalf of all land-holders in respect to the Caroline Springs project.

It is true that Caroline Springs Nominees Pty Ltd is not a wholly-owned subsidiary but the Gilbertson group owns 472 of the 670 ordinary shares on issue by that company—so they control it. And that company has the land, I understand, just west of Melbourne—Senator Carr might be more familiar with it—which will be the subject of the Caroline Springs joint venture with Delfin corporation, which the Australian Securities Commission advised me today is likely to net in excess of $115 million to the Gilbertson group of companies. Yet this is the same group of companies that says that they do not have enough money to pay the workers and the small businesses of Grafton.

It is also interesting that the list of companies offered as guarantors in the letter of 25 March does not include Dromana Meat Company Pty Ltd and Greenham Abattoirs. This is interesting because both of those companies were parties to the deed of revocation dated 26 June 1997—in other words, they would normally, if these companies had been put into liquidation, have had to cough up for the debts of the companies which are insolvent. But they have been excluded, just like Caroline Springs Nominees Pty Ltd.

Dromana Meat Company is an interesting story. Honourable senators might like to know about this one. Dromana Meat Company was the company which the Gilbertson family tried to put into voluntary liquidation in 1992. Indeed, the company was actually dissolved in 1993. There is only one little problem: in 1994 a Judith Vagg approached the court and succeeded in getting an order for the company's dissolution to be declared void. I have not had the opportunity to contact Judith Vagg or her lawyer, but I put everybody on notice of the fact that I will be contacting her lawyer tomorrow because I believe that she is a creditor who has not been paid out and who has, in fact, been hidden in the process of the liquidation. But certainly the Gilbertson group has a habit of playing loose and fast with insolvency administrations. And here we find another example.

And while the workers and the small businesses of Grafton struggle, where are the Gilbertson family? In Melbourne, in Camberwell, in Hawthorn and the leafy suburbs enjoying the fact that these companies, if they have their way, will net them all the benefits, and the losses will be left with the unsecured creditors in Grafton.

talk.start.para: —So are you supporting the AMIEU?
—I am actually supporting the AMIEU because we are working together to ensure that justice is done and mark my words, justice will be done.

—I wish to make a couple of comments about a particular publication called the Tasmanian Master Builder , which I have in my possession and which I intend to table later. It is the edition for March 1998. It draws attention to the parlous state of the building industry in Tasmania. In 1996-97 we had 119 building apprenticeship commencements. Going back to the early days of 1987-88, we had 308; in 1995-96, 135; and in 1996-97, only 12 months ago, we had 119 building apprenticeship commencements. I am sorry to say that for 1997-98 the total number of building apprenticeship commencements in Tasmania is 49. We are doing it tough in some areas of the economy in Tasmania. Some other areas are doing quite well.

speech.para: I have been supporting a particular project that has been put forward as a federation project. It was first proposed by the Tasmanian Building and Construction Training Board as a training project to improve the situation of building apprenticeships in Tasmania. If this project were to attain federal funding of some $14 million over four years it would provide the opportunity for something like 200 traineeships or apprenticeships and an additional 300 construction jobs. We have the situation in Tasmania at the moment where these construction workers and building apprentices are leaving the state because of the lack of work. It needs a circuit breaker at the moment. There are a lot of projects on the drawing board but not too many of them are coming to fruition at the moment. So federal intervention with a Federation Fund grant would certainly go a long way to alleviating the problem.

This particular project has the support of Senator Harradine, Senator Brown, myself, Senator Gibson, Senator Abetz, Senator Mackay, Senator O'Brien, Senator Sherry, Duncan Kerr, Dick Adams and Harry Quick. Warwick Smith wants to support it but he has a few doubts about its viability. Some of my colleagues are undecided and a couple of others have yet to reply. This project has the support of the union movement, most of the Labor Party and most of the Liberal Party. It is a very important project. It is something that is sorely needed in my state to alleviate the decline in building apprenticeships.

Just today I was pleased to have the chairman of the AFL proposal, Mr Dick Watson, here to talk to some of the representatives on the Federation Fund board to put the case to them and show them how serious we are about this and what this may do for Tasmania.

There has been a lot of misinformation about this project. The fact of the matter is that we are the only state in Australia that does not have a stadium with lights or an international type facility for international sporting teams—cricket teams or football teams—or international artists, which every other state has. It would be most appropriate to have a stadium dedicated in the year 2000 to the federation of our wonderful country there in the capital city of Hobart.

This particular project has brought out the best in parochial interest in Tasmania, as these sorts of things normally do. There are some people who would like to see it built at Oatlands or Burnie or Launceston. But when I left Tasmania last Sunday Hobart was still the capital city and I would think that a facility like this should be in the capital city. It would be something that the state would look at with great pride in the years to come.

There is no doubt that a stadium like this would attract Australian Rules Football teams to play roster games there. This particular project is based on some of the clubs playing there. North Melbourne and Hawthorne have already indicated that they would like to play some of their roster games there. In fact, two practice matches there in January, when there were other events on in Tasmania, attracted crowds of 15,000 and 12,000 people respectively. That was to practice games. I think that indicates the great following that Australian Rules Football has in Tasmania. Having said that, we have also produced many fine players. I fear that unless we have a facility to allow AFL teams to play in Tasmania then the AFL will lose an area that has been very productive in the past in producing footballers of the ilk of Baldock, Hudson and the like, who have enhanced the Australian Rules Football game in Australia.

I seek leave to table this particular special edition of the Tasmanian Master Builder, which points out the advantages of a construction project that has been highlighted—the super stadium project. The project would improve facilities for agriculture and for cricket, football and other sports in Tasmania, provided it got small help from the federal government. I hope that in the considerations that are coming up in the next month or so the AFL project, which has the support of the state government, does gain the recognition and support that is needed to help the apprenticeships and building workers that are needed so urgently in Tasmania.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: Up to 24 March 1998, a total of 247 ADF personnel had been assigned to the Gulf area. Many of those personnel, particularly RAAF aircrew transited into and out of the Gulf during transport operations.
